title: 106_hr1490
content: The Act titled "National Parks Capital Improvements Act of 1999" includes sections on definitions, fundraising organizations, memorandum of agreement, national park surcharge, use of bond proceeds, and administration. The Act also provides a table of contents outlining the different sections. In this Act, key definitions include fundraising organization, memorandum of agreement, National Park Foundation, and national park. The Act establishes terms for these entities and specifies the Grand Canyon National Park as well as other designated national parks. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, who must have an approved general management plan with capital needs exceeding $5,000,000. SEC. 3. FUNDRAISING ORGANIZATION. The Secretary may enter into a memorandum of agreement with an entity to act as an authorized fundraising organization for a national park. The fundraising organization shall issue taxable bonds in return for the surcharge collected for that national park. It must comply with professional standards and be subject to an audit by the Secretary. The United States is not liable for the security of any bonds issued by the fundraising organization. The full faith and credit of the United States is pledged to the payment of bonds issued by a fundraising organization for a national park, as well as the interest accruing on the bonds. The fundraising organization must enter into a memorandum of agreement detailing the bond issue, maturity not exceeding 20 years, per capita amount for bond repayment and administration costs, specific park projects funded by bonds, and procedures for agreement modifications. The Secretary may authorize a national park superintendent to charge a surcharge of up to $2 per individual in addition to entrance fees collected under specific acts. The Secretary may authorize a national park superintendent to charge a surcharge of up to $2 per individual in addition to entrance fees collected under specific acts. The total amount charged or set aside may not exceed $2 for each individual charged an entrance fee. The surcharge shall be used to amortize the bond issue, cover administration costs, and maintain a reserve as determined by the bond underwriter. Any excess funds collected will be handled accordingly. Any excess funds collected from surcharges at national parks shall be remitted to the National Park Foundation for the benefit of the National Park System. SEC. 6. USE OF BOND PROCEEDS. Bond proceeds under this Act can be used for projects in national parks, subject to certain limitations. Projects must comply with laws governing the National Park System, the specific national park, and its general management plan. Bond proceeds cannot be used for administrative expenses, except for interest. Interest earned on bond proceeds can be used by the fundraising organization to meet reserve requirements and cover administrative expenses related to bond management. Any excess interest not used for these purposes must be given to the National Park Foundation for the benefit of all units in the National Park System. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Treasury, will create regulations to implement the Act.
